Derek Pappas wrote (offlist, but was OK with an on-list reply):
> Gordon,
> 
> You may or may not be interested to see what the Hertrix traffic pattern 
> looks like over a two week period.
> All four crawlers were restarted two weeks ago.
> 
> There are 4 computers running crawlers and the traffic pattern slows 
> over time even though the queue size is increasing.
[screenshot of H1 console and of bandwidth graph was attached]

It's normal for the rate to slow, for a variety of different reasons. 
But that rate (<10 URI/sec) is suspiciously slow for having so many 
independent queues to crawl (load factor 16+), and all threads (50) active.

What's the hardware like?

Might the machine be swapping?

Are there other busy/memory-intensive processes active on the same machine?

Could a majority of the sites targeted by live queues be not responding 
to your connect requests, and thus encountering both slow (20-30 second) 
socket timeouts, and slow (15 minute) retry cycles? This could be the 
case if sites have explicitly blocked your IP, or if you've hit a large 
collection of related trap sites (such as wildcard subdomains) that are 
all unresponsive/intentionally-slow. The frontier report provides the 
best clues if this is happening.

Also, the 'out' bandwidth is *so* smooth for long periods that there 
could be a cap or other traffic shaping on some overburdened link 
between the machine and the net.

- Gordon
